is a seaside village in the north coast of the

value: Durness can be reached by roads from

, or along the north coast from Thurso. Note the long distances involved - over 165 km to Inverness, or 110 km to Thurso. Much of these roads are single-track, and twisty in places, so driving can be slow.
, via Ullapool. This runs Monday to Saturday, plus Sundays in July and August. This has a trailer to carry bicycles (bicycles must be booked at least 24hrs in advance).
Bus from Durness to Lairg operated by
, goes to Lairg train station, connecting with trains from Inverness. Runs Monday to Saturday, all year.
Bus from Durness to Inverness, operated by
. Runs throughout the year, one or two Saturdays per month, advance booking recommended.
Bus from Durness to Thurso, operated by
. Runs throughout the year, one or two Saturdays per month, advance booking recommended.
watch wildlife: sea birds (including puffins north of Durness), seals and porpoises.

There is tourist information centre by the road.

value: , the most north-westerly point in mainland Scotland. This involves a ferry across the Kyle of Durness, then a minibus along the road to the cape. Or you can walk or cycle along (about 18km each way). There is a lighthouse with a cafe at the cape.
take a boat trip for whale spotting
- often good close-up views of seals in the rock pools. At the correct season eider ducks swimming in with their ducklings from far away make an impressive and memorable sight.
There is a well stocked local Spar which doubles as the post office.

There is a camping up on the cliff over Sango Bay. 
There are also several B&Bs in the village and a handful of self-catering establishments.

value: alt=self catering both in and outside Durness

There is ATM and petrol station in the village.
